title: Nicked Blade After Cutting Meat
vignette: A butcher finds micro-chips on his knife post-cut.

options.text: The meat is invalid; the cut may have torn.
If the nick is minor, the slaughter stands.

title: Third-Party Completes Required Step
vignette: A kitchen porter finishes a mandatory food-prep step before the chef can.

options.text: The duty is lost and the meat remains approved.
He should slaughter again to perform the command himself.

title: Stunning before slaughter
vignette: To minimize pain, an electric stunner is used prior to slaughter.

options.text: Permissible if the animal remains alive for the cut.
Forbidden; stunning disqualifies the slaughter.

title: Unknown Cause of Death for Poultry
vignette: A headless chicken is found in the yard—no one saw what happened.

options.text: Assume improper slaughter and forbid eating.
Presume it was slaughtered correctly and permit it.

title: Brief Pressure vs. Clean Slice
vignette: During carving, the knife may have pressed rather than sliced for an instant.

options.text: Any doubt invalidates the meat.
If most of the cut was smooth, it is allowed.

title: Assistance from Uncertified Personnel
vignette: A certified lead technician is performing a critical, regulated procedure. An uncertified assistant helps by holding the equipment steady.

options.text: Valid as long as the certified technician performs the critical action.
Invalid; only certified personnel may handle the equipment during the procedure.

title: Parasites in One Piece After Joint Salting
vignette: Liver cured with other cuts is later found to have parasites.

options.text: If worms are found, all meat must be discarded.
Only the liver is suspect; the rest is fine.

title: Forbidden Fat Mixed Into Approved Batch
vignette: A small amount of non-compliant fat melts into a vat of approved product.

options.text: Any amount taints the entire batch.
Follow the sixty-to-one rule; nullify if small enough.

title: Found needle in cow's stomach
vignette: During inspection, a needle is discovered stuck in the stomach lining.

options.text: The animal is approved unless the organ was punctured.
The mere presence forbids the meat.

title: Cooked Meat Touches Non-Compliant Tray
vignette: Grilled steak briefly rests on a tray from an unregulated kitchen.

options.text: It absorbs forbidden taste and must be discarded.
Quick contact doesn't matter; wipe it off and eat.

title: Exporting Products That Don't Meet Domestic Standards
vignette: A food manufacturer produces a product that doesn't meet strict domestic purity/ingredient standards due to costly processing steps. However, these standards are not required in a major export market.

options.text: Permissible to export the product. The standards are for the domestic market, and the export market has its own regulations which are met.
Refuse to export. Selling a product abroad that you wouldn't sell at home is unethical and could damage the company's reputation if discovered.

title: Tithing obligations for domesticated birds
vignette: Someone raises doves at home and wonders if they require tithing like livestock.

options.text: Yes; designate a portion as sacred.
No formal tithing applies to household birds.

title: Unsourced Hide for Archival Paper
vignette: A parchment supplier uses leather of unknown origin for official documents.

options.text: Acceptable if tanned properly.
Only hides from approved slaughter may be used.

title: Mixing meat and fish in one dish
vignette: A stew accidentally combines chicken pieces with fish fillets.

options.text: Eat it; the combination is safe though unconventional.
Avoid eating due to health and custom concerns.

title: Disposing of Improperly Processed Meat
vignette: Meat from an unapproved slaughter method is on hand—feed pets or discard respectfully?

options.text: Allowed; no prohibition on benefit.
Better to bury it out of respect.
